vocabulary.details: A ubiquitous protein in Thai cuisine, found in everything from street food skewers to curries and stir-fries.
Another staple protein, featured in popular dishes like 'moo ping' (grilled pork skewers) and various stir-fries.
Crispy deep-fried pork belly, a popular street food and ingredient in stir-fries like 'pad kana moo krop' (ผัดคะน้าหมูกรอบ).
Commonly found in soups, curries, and grilled dishes. It's usually shortened to just เนื้อ (néua). The full, more formal term is เนื้อวัว (néua wua), where วัว (wua) means 'cow'.
Often roasted, called เป็ดย่าง (bpèt yâang), or served in noodle soups.
A very popular seafood choice, central to dishes like Tom Yum Goong (ต้มยำกุ้ง).
Can be steamed, fried, or grilled and is a staple protein source.

Often grilled or used in stir-fries and salads. The casual term is just หมึก (mèuk). The full term is ปลาหมึก (bplaa mèuk), which literally means 'ink fish', as ปลา (bplaa) means 'fish' and หมึก (mèuk) means 'ink'.
A popular seafood item, especially in coastal areas. Famous in the dish ปูผัดผงกะหรี่ (bpoo pàt pŏng gà-rèe), or stir-fried crab with curry powder.
Frequently served as a fried egg, ไข่ดาว (kài daao), or in an omelette, ไข่เจียว (kài jiao).

azure_pron_mapping.translation: bean curd; tofu (as in เต้าหู้)

vocabulary.details: A common vegetarian protein option, available in various forms. This is a loanword from Chinese and is treated as a single word.

azure_pron_mapping.translation: water spinach (as in ผักบุ้ง)

vocabulary.details: A popular leafy green, famously stir-fried as ผัดผักบุ้งไฟแดง (pàt pàk-bûng fai daeng).
Commonly used in stir-fries, often with crispy pork in the dish คะน้าหมูกรอบ (ká-náa mŏo gròp).

Used in various dishes from stir-fries to soups. The common name is often shortened to กะหล่ำ (gà-làm). The full name is กะหล่ำปลี (gà-làm-bplee), where ปลี (bplee) refers to a blossom or head of a plant.
The key ingredient, when unripe and green, for the famous papaya salad, ส้มตำ (sôm dtam).
Adds a crunchy texture to curries and stir-fries.
A common ingredient in noodle dishes like Pad Thai (ผัดไทย) and as a side for soups.
A staple in Thai soups and curries, providing a citrusy aroma.
Similar to ginger but with a more peppery and citrusy flavor, essential for soups like Tom Yum (ต้มยำ) and Tom Kha (ต้มข่า).
Different from galangal, it provides a spicier heat and is used in many stir-fries and sauces.

azure_pron_mapping.translation: kaffir lime (as in มะกรูด)

vocabulary.details: Adds a unique citrusy and floral aroma to soups and curries.
The foundation of spiciness in Thai cuisine, used fresh and dried. A common small but very spicy variety is called พริกขี้หนู (prík kee noo).
A fundamental aromatic used in almost all savory dishes.
Provide a sweet and pungent flavor to many dishes. Literally 'red onion' or 'fragrant red'.
Has a peppery, clove-like flavor and is the star of Thailand's famous stir-fry, Pad Krapow (ผัดกะเพรา).
Often used in curries like Green Curry, แกงเขียวหวาน (gaeng kĭeow wăan), and has a sweet, anise-like flavor.
A key ingredient pounded with garlic (กระเทียม) and white peppercorns (พริกไทยขาว) to form a foundational aromatic paste called สามเกลอ (săam gler), or 'three buddies'.
Used for its yellow color and earthy flavor, especially in Southern Thai cuisine.
The primary source of saltiness in Thai cuisine, used in countless dishes. A popular chili dipping sauce made with it is พริกน้ำปลา (prík nám-bplaa).
A thick, savory sauce used in many stir-fries.
A loanword from Teochew Chinese. Comes in a light, salty version called ซีอิ๊วขาว (see-éw kăao), 'white soy sauce', and a dark, sweet version called ซีอิ๊วดำ (see-éw dam), 'black soy sauce'.

vocabulary.thai: เต้าเจี้ยว
vocabulary.details: A salty, savory paste used to add umami depth to stir-fries and sauces.
The creamy base for most Thai curries and many desserts.

vocabulary.thai: น้ำตาลปี๊บ
vocabulary.details: A traditional sweetener with a deep, caramel-like flavor. The name comes from น้ำตาล (nám-dtaan) for 'sugar' and ปี๊บ (bpíip) for the 'tin/can' it was traditionally sold in. A more specific term is น้ำตาลมะพร้าว (nám-dtaan má-práao), or 'coconut sugar'.

azure_pron_mapping.translation: juice of / water of (prefix for fruits)

vocabulary.details: Provides a sour taste to dishes like Pad Thai and some curries. The full term is น้ำมะขามเปียก (nám má-kăam bpìak), where เปียก (bpìak) means 'wet', referring to the wet paste form.
vocabulary.formal: น้ำมะขามเปียก

vocabulary.details: One of the core flavors of Thai cuisine.
A key flavor, often from lime, มะนาว (má-naao), or tamarind, มะขาม (má-kăam), that balances richness.
A fundamental taste, usually from fish sauce, น้ำปลา (nám bplaa), or soy sauce, ซีอิ๊ว (see éw).
A defining characteristic of many Thai dishes.
A general term for a wide variety of dipping sauces served with Thai food.
A desirable texture in many fried dishes and some salads.

vocabulary.thai: กระเทียมเจียว
vocabulary.details: A common garnish that adds a crunchy, savory flavor.
Another popular crispy garnish, adding a sweet and savory crunch.
The fresh leaves are used as a garnish for almost every type of dish, adding a fresh, citrusy note.

vocabulary.thai: ผักชีฝรั่ง
vocabulary.details: Literally 'foreign coriander'. Has a much stronger, more pungent flavor than regular cilantro and is often used in soups and spicy salads.
Often crushed and sprinkled on top of salads and noodle dishes for texture and flavor. The full, formal term is ถั่วลิสงคั่ว (tùa lí-sŏng kûa), where ลิสง (lí-sŏng) specifically means 'peanut'.
vocabulary.formal: ถั่วลิสงคั่ว

vocabulary.details: A common condiment, usually made from dry-roasted chilis, to add extra heat to dishes.
